nitf_BlockingInfo_print - Print blocking information

nitf_ImageIO_setReadCaching - Enable cached reads

nitf_ImageIO_destruct deallocates the memory associated with the object. The argument is set to NULL on return

Parameters:

Returns:
None
See the documentation for nitf_ImageWriter_setReadCaching

Returns:

< Object to modify

nitf_BlockingInfo_print doe a formatted print of a nitf_BlockingInfo structure.

If the "file" argument is NULL stdout is used.

Returns:
None
Turn the geographic value into a string. You must have a buffer with 7 elements to hand in to this function, otherwise you will have memory corruption.

Turn the decimal value into a string +-dd.ddd. You must have a buffer with 7 elements to hand in to this function, otherwise you will have memory corruption.

Turn the decimal value into a string +-ddd.ddd. You must have a buffer with 7 elements to hand in to this function, otherwise you will have memory corruption.

Replace the oldValue with the newValue within this string

Turn the geographic value into a string. You must have a buffer with 7 elements to hand in to this function, otherwise you will have memory corruption.

Turn the decimal value into a string +-dd.ddd. You must have a buffer with 7 elements to hand in to this function, otherwise you will have memory corruption.

Turn the decimal value into a string +-ddd.ddd. You must have a buffer with 7 elements to hand in to this function, otherwise you will have memory corruption.

NITFPROT ( NITF_BOOL   ) 

nitf_ImageIO_writeDone - Cleanup for write

nitf_ImageIO_setFileOffset

nitf_ImageIO_read - Read a sub-window

nitf_ImageIO_flush - Complete deferred writes

nitf_ImageIO_writeRows - Write rows more rows

TODO: Add documentation

Resizes the field, if it is allowed to be resized. It returns false if the resizable member of the field is false. Otherwise, it attempts to resize the field, which will destroy the current raw data.

nitf_ImageIOWrite_writeDone does post writing clean-up for the calling object.

All memory allocated for the write operation is freed and any deferred write operations are complete. The deferred writes are done by calling the flush operation.

Parameters:
object Object to cleanup
io io interface to use
error [out] The error to return
Returns:
One error, FALSE is returned and the caller supplied error object is set.
Possible errors:

Writer not active I/O errors Memory allocation errors Invalid row count

nitf_ImageIO_writeRows writes consecutive rows to the image. The rows are written after the rows of the previous call. This function is for sequential writes of complete rows

The "data" argument is an array of pointers. Each pointer points to the row data for one band. When multiple rows are written (numRows != 1), Each pointer points to numRows rows of data for that band. The pointers should be ordered according to the band order.

The image I/O object must be set-up for write by one of the following functions:

nitf_ImageIO_writeSequential

Parameters:
object Associated ImageIO object
io Interface for writes
data Row buffers, one per band
erro For error reports
Returns:
One error, FALSE is returned and the caller supplied error object is set.
Possible errors:

Writer not active I/O errors Memory allocation errors Invalid row count

nitf_ImageIO_flush completes any deferred write associated with the calling object. An example of something that might be deferred is the writing of the block mask.

Parameters:
The object to flush
io The interface pointer
error [out] error to return
Returns:
On error, FALSE is returned and the supplied error object is set
Possible errors include:

Writer not active I/O errors

nitf_ImageIO_read reads a sub-window. The user supplies the opened file descriptor and data buffers. The file should allow seeks. The file is left in the file position of the last read.

If the padded argument returns TRUE the request may include pad pixels. For blocked images, each block may contain pad pixels. It is possible to determine that a given block contains pads but it is not always possible to tell which ones. So a request may hit a block with pad pixels but miss the actual pixels. Thus the padded flag is only a maybe. A FALSE value does mean that there are not pad pixels in the request.

The user must supply one buffer for each band requested in the sub-window. Each buffer must have enough storage for one band of the requested sub-window size.

Row and column skips of more than one in the sub-window are not currently implemented.

Parameters:
nitf The associated nitf_ImageIO object
io The IO interface
subWindow Sub-window to read
padded Returns TRUE if pad pixels may have been read
error [out] Error object
Returns:
Returns FALSE on error
On error, FALSE is returned and the user supplied error object is set.

Possible errors include:

Write in progress Invalid sub-set or band System I/O or memory allocation errors

nitf_ImageIO_setFileOffset sets the file offset to the start of the image data. This resets the value given as the offset argument of the nitf_ImageIO contructor. This value cannot be changed if an I/O operation is in progress.

Parameters:
nitf 
offset The associated nitf_ImageIO offset
error Error object
Returns:
FALSE is returned on error and teh error object is set
Possible errors include:

I/O operation in progress
